head.title: Read On, All You Book Lovers, Read On

hedline.hl1: Read On, All You Book Lovers, Read On

abstract.p: List of activities related to New York Is Book Country fair (S)

block.p: A variety of book-related activities, including screenings, readings and panel discussions, are planned at museums, libraries and elsewhere in New York City this weekend in conjunction with the New York Is Book Country fair, which is to be held on Sunday on Fifth Avenue (www.nyisbookcountry.com). Unless otherwise noted, events are free; programs are subject to change.
Today
READING, Bluestockings: Women's Bookstore, 172 Allen Street, Lower Manhattan. With Rahna Reiko Rizzuto, author of ''Why She Left Us.'' 7 to 9 p.m. Information: (212) 777-6028.

A variety of book-related activities, including screenings, readings and panel discussions, are planned at museums, libraries and elsewhere in New York City this weekend in conjunction with the New York Is Book Country fair, which is to be held on Sunday on Fifth Avenue (www.nyisbookcountry.com). Unless otherwise noted, events are free; programs are subject to change.
Today
READING, Bluestockings: Women's Bookstore, 172 Allen Street, Lower Manhattan. With Rahna Reiko Rizzuto, author of ''Why She Left Us.'' 7 to 9 p.m. Information: (212) 777-6028.
BOOKMAKING DEMONSTRATION, Center for Book Arts, 28 West 27th Street, third floor, Chelsea. 4 to 8 p.m. Information: (212) 481-0295.

READINGS, Jazz Gallery, 290 Hudson Street, second floor, Greenwich Village. ''Riffing on Literature and Jazz: A Literary Jam Session,'' with Charlotte Carter (''Drumsticks,'' ''Coq au Vin'' and ''Rhode Island Red''); Stanley Crouch (''Don't the Moon Look Lonesome''); Rafi Zabor (''The Bear Comes Home''); and David Earl Jackson, as master of ceremonies. 7 to 8:30 p.m. Information: (212) 368-2436.
TOUR, New York Academy of Medicine, 1216 Fifth Avenue, at 103rd Street. A tour of the library and conservation laboratory. 10 a.m., noon and 2 p.m. Information: (212) 822-7323.

PANEL DISCUSSION, N.Y.U. Center for Publishing, 11 West 42nd Street, Room 1027. ''The Future of the Book,'' moderated by Robert E. Baensch, director of the center, with guest speakers from the electronic and online publishing industries; 5:30 to 7 p.m. Reservations: (212) 790-3232.

AUTHOR TALK WITH MUSIC, Loft, 295 East Eighth Street, East Village. A discussion on ''Book Into Film,'' with Roland Legiardi Laura, a filmmaker and director of the Nuyorican Poet's Cafe; Josette Piacenti will sing book-related arias. 7 to 9 p.m. Sponsored by the Odysseus Group and Oxford Village Press. Fee, $10. Reservations required: (212) 529-9327 or (212) 529-9397.
Tomorrow

BOOKMAKING WORKSHOP, American Craft Museum, 40 West 53d Street, Manhattan. ''Fun Little Books''; 10:30 a.m. to 12:30 p.m. Free with museum admission, $5; $2.50 for students and the elderly; free for children under 12. Reservations necessary: (212) 956-3535.

READINGS, Bank Street College, auditorium, 610 West 112th Street, Manhattan. With Anthony Bourdain (''Kitchen Confidential: Adventures in the Culinary Underbelly''); Tim Cockey (''The Hearse You Came In On''); and Susan Orlean (''The Orchid Thief''), 4 to 6 p.m. Sponsored by New Atlantic Independent Booksellers Association. Information: (516) 333-0681.

POETRY READING, Bloomingdale Regional Library, 150 West 100th Street, Manhattan. Dennis Nurske (''Leaving Xaia'') and Martha Rhodes (''Perfect Disappearance''), 2 to 3:30 p.m. Information: (212) 222-8030.
READING, Bluestockings Women's Bookstore, 172 Allen Street, Lower Manhattan. Hattie Gossett (''Presenting . . . Sister No blues''), 7 to 9 p.m. Information: (212) 777-6028.

READINGS, Brooklyn Moon Cafe, 745 Fulton Street, Fort Greene. Victor LaValle (''Slapboxing With Jesus''); Ernesto Quinonez (''Bodega Dreams''); and others, 9 p.m. Sponsored by QBR: The Black Book Review. Fee, $5. Information: (718) 243-0424.

READINGS, Brooklyn Public Library, Grand Army Plaza, at the intersection of Eastern Parkway and Flatbush Avenue. Cheryl and Wade Hudson (''In Praise of Our Fathers and Mothers''), 4:30 to 5 p.m.; Deborah Gregory (''Wishing on a Star''), 3 to 4 p.m.; Donna Clovis (''The Locket of Dreams''), 1 to 1:30 p.m.; Omar Tyree (''For the Love of Money'' and ''Fly Girl''), noon to 1 and 4 to 5 p.m. Also a bilingual puppet show, noon to 1 p.m. in the second-floor auditorium and arts and crafts demonstrations, noon to 1 p.m. Sponsored by African Voices Magazine. Information: (212) 865-2982 or (718) 230-2100.

STORIES AND ART, Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park. With Stephen Kroninger, illustrator of ''Tie Your Shoes and Clap Your Feet,'' 4 p.m. Free with museum admission: $4; $2 for students and the elderly; free for members and children under 12. Information: (718) 638-5000, extension 230.

READINGS AND PANEL DISCUSSION, Caribbean Cultural Center, 408 West 58th Street, Manhattan. With Sheree R. Thomas, editor of ''Dark Matter: A Century of Speculative Fiction From the African Diaspora.'' 3 to 5 p.m. Information: (212) 307-7420.
READING AND DISCUSSION, Countee Cullen Regional Library, 104 West 136th Street, Manhattan. David Dent (''In Search of Black America''), 2:30 to 3:30 p.m. Information: (212) 491-2070.

COOKING DEMONSTRATIONS, Eli's Manhattan, 1411 Third Avenue, at 80th Street, Manhattan. Jayne Cohen (''Gefilte Fish Variations'') at 11 a.m.; Lauren Chattman (''Instant Gratification'') at noon. Jack Bishop (''Pasta e Verdura'') at 1 p.m.; Michele Scicolone (''La Dolce Vita'') at 2 p.m.; Cheryl Mendelson (''Home Comforts'') at 3 p.m.; Rosa Ross (''New Wok Cooking'') at 4 p.m.; and the Moosewood Collective (''Moosewood Restaurant Daily Specials'') at 5 p.m. Information: (212) 717-8100.
READING/DISCUSSION, Epiphany Branch Library, 228 East 23rd Street, Manhattan. Rona Jaffe (''The Road Taken''), 2 to 3 p.m. Information: (212) 679-2645.
READING AND CONVERSATION, 58th Street Branch Library, 127 East 58th Street, Manhattan. Whit Stillman (''The Last Days of Disco''), 2 p.m. Information: (212) 759-7358.

READING AND SINGING, Langston Hughes Branch Library, 100-01 Northern Boulevard, Corona, Queens. Rachel Bagby (''Divining Daughters' Voices: A Polycultural Inquiry), 2 to 4 p.m. Information: (718) 651-1100 or (718) 990-8549.
READING, Laurelton Branch Library, 134-26 225th Street, Queens. Kristin Clark Taylor (''Black Mothers: Songs of Praise and Celebration''), 2 p.m. Information: (718) 528-2822.

STORYTELLING AND ILLUSTRATION WORKSHOPS, Lefferts Homestead Children's Historic House Museum, Prospect Park, near Empire Boulevard, Brooklyn. Stories from ''The Social History of Flatbush'' by Gertrude Lefferts Vanderbilt. 1 to 4 p.m. Information: (718) 965-6505.

READINGS, Museum of the City of New York, 1220 Fifth Avenue, at 103rd Street. Jane Mushabac and Angela Wigan (''A Short and Remarkable History of New York City''), 2 to 3:30 p.m. Free with museum contribution: $7; $4 for students and the elderly; $12 for families. Information: (212) 534-1672, extension 257.

SCREENING AND READING WITH MARC BROWN, Museum of Television and Radio, 25 West 52d Street, Manhattan. A screening of ''Arthur's Chickenpox'' and a reading of ''Arthur's Teacher Moves In.'' 1 to 2 p.m. Free with museum admission: $7; $6 for students and the elderly; $3 for children under 13. Information: (212) 621-6600.

READINGS, National Museum of the American Indian, Alexander Hamilton United States Custom House, 1 Bowling Green, second floor, Lower Manhattan. Clinton Elliott (''Ojibway Stories'') and Paul Betancourt (''Iroquois Stories''), 12:30 to 4:30 p.m. Information: (212) 514-3700.

READINGS AND WORKSHOPS, New York City Fire Museum, 278 Spring Street, SoHo. Appearances by Kevin the Firefighter and Hooper, a fire dog. 11 a.m. to noon; Chris Demarest (''Firefighters A to Z''), noon to 1:30 p.m.; Joy Masoff (''Fire!''), 1:30 to 3 p.m. Donations suggested. Information: (212) 691-1303.

READING, New York Hall of Science, 47-01 111th Street, Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, Queens. With Jean Marzollo (''I Spy'' and the ''I Am'' books for Scholastic's ''Hello Reader! Science Series''), 1 to 3 p.m. Free with museum admission, $7.50; $5 for children 4 to 17; under 4, free. Information: (718) 699-0005.

READING, New-York Historical Society, 2 West 77th Street, Manhattan. William Styple (''The Little Bugler: The True Story of a 12-Year-Old Boy in the Civil War''). 2 to 3 p.m. Free with museum admission, $5; $3 for students and the elderly. Information: (212) 873-3400.

''GAMES, TRICKS, TOYS AND TREATS,'' New York Transit Museum Gallery and Store, Grand Central Terminal. With Michael Makman (''Metrocard Mania With Professor Putter''), 1 to 3 p.m. Information: (718) 243-8601.
READING AND CONVERSATION, 96th Street Regional Library, 112 East 96th Street, Manhattan. Jeffrey Renard Allen (''Rails Under My Back''), 2 to 4 p.m. Information: (212) 289-0908.
READING, 115th Street Branch Library, 203 West 115th Street, Manhattan. Bell Hooks (''All About Love: New Visions''), 2 p.m. Information: (212) 666-9393.
POETRY READING, Riverside Branch Library, 127 Amsterdam Avenue, at 65th Street, Manhattan. Jane Shore (''Happy Family: Poems''), 2:30 to 4 p.m. Information: (212) 870-1810.
BOOKMAKING WORKSHOP, SONY Wonder Technology Lab, 550 Madison Avenue, at 56th Street. Create a ''wonderbot'' tale. 11 a.m. to 1 p.m. Fee: $3. Information: (212) 833-4698.
AUTHOR TALK, Windsor Park Branch, 79-50 Bell Boulevard, Bayside, Queens. Michael Skakun (''On Burning Ground: A Son's Memoir''), 2 to 3:30 p.m. Information: (718) 990-0896 or (718)468-8300.
POETRY READING, Woodside Branch Library, 54-22 Skillman Avenue, Queens. Eugene Gloria (''Drivers at the Short-Time Motel''), 2:30 to 3:30 p.m. Information: (718) 990-0896 or (718) 429-4700.
